Overview

Overview

  1. What is the grammar of graphics?
  2. Building plots in ggplot2

The grammar of graphics

How do we describe the basic structure shared by all visualisations?

How do we avoid bad connections between data and visuals?

The ‘grammar’

  • The ‘gg’ in ggplot2 stands for ‘grammar of graphics’.
  • What’s the grammar?

…a statistical graphic is a mapping from data to aesthetic attributes (colour, shape, size) of geometric objects (points, lines, bars). The plot may also contain statistical transformations of the data and is drawn on a specific coordinate system. (Wickham 2016, 4)

  • See: The Grammar of Graphics (Wilkinson 2005).

Data and mappings

  1. Data
    • assumed to be ‘tidy’
  2. ‘Aesthetic mappings’
    • From columns to a visual property.

Layers

  1. Layers
    • The elements of the plot you actually see.
    • Geometrical objects (geoms) display the data.
    • Statistical transformations (stats), provide a visual summary.

Scales and coordinates

  1. Scales and coordinates
    • Scales specify the aesthetic mapping.
      • e.g. use this shade of blue to represent “Female”.
    • Coordinates determine the axes of the plot.

Facets and themes

  1. Facets
    • divide the data into groups and plot separately.
  2. Theme
    • additional visual details of the plot, e.g., font size and background colour.

Grammar of graphics summary

  1. Data
  2. Aesthetic mappings
  3. Layers
  4. Scales and coordinates
  5. Facets
  6. Theme

Using ggplot2

The ggplot() function

prints |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  )
  • Apply the ggplot() function to vowels.
  • Establish an overall aesthetic mapping (with aes)

What’s the output?

The ggplot() function

The ggplot() function (2)

  • We don’t have any layers yet
  • But ggplot() has already set:
    • scales and coordinates, and
    • a theme.
  • Usually these are sensible defaults.

Add layers

prints |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_point()
  • NB: use of + (not %>% or |>)
  • geom_points() creates a scatter plot.
  • Most layers come in functions starting with geom_
  • See: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/#layers

Add layers

Switch to geom_jitter()

prints |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3)
  • geom_jitter() applies random scatter to points.
  • Can be helpful for seeing number of data points in location.
  • Note width: all geom_ functions have options.
  • See the documentation (or cheat sheets etc)

Switch to geom_jitter()

Add a summary

prints |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3) +
  geom_smooth(method="lm")
  • geom_smooth() fits a model.
  • Applies separately to groups in data (guess from aesthetic mapping).

Add a summary

Override aesthetic mapping

prints |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3) +
  geom_smooth(
    aes(x=corsi_fwd, y=fingerprint), 
    inherit.aes=FALSE, 
    method="lm"
  )
  • Now geom_smooth() will only make one line.

Override aesthetic mapping

Modify colour scale

prints |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3) +
  scale_colour_manual(
    values = c(
      "Female" = "#004488",
      "Male" = "#ddaa33",
      "Non-Binary" = "#bb5566"
    )
  )
  • Most scaling functions start with scale_
  • scale_colour_ will often just affect outlines.
  • If you have this problem, try scale_fill_
  • Lots of advice out there for picking colours.
  • See viridis package for some nice colour-blind friendly pallettes.

Modify colour scale

Faceting

prints |> 
  mutate(
    age_cat = if_else(age < 35, "18-34", "35+")
  ) |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3) +
  scale_colour_manual(
    values = c(
      "Female" = "#004488",
      "Male" = "#ddaa33",
      "Non-Binary" = "#bb5566"
    )
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    cols = vars(age_cat)
  )
  • Recall mutate() from the previous workshop.
  • Use facet_grid() to specify rows and columns manually.
  • Use facet_wrap() to use rows and columns for a single variable.
    • e.g. a facet for 10 distinct participants.
  • You have to use vars() to identify the variable to facet by.

Faceting

Fix up labels

prints |> 
  mutate(
    age_cat = if_else(age < 35, "18-34", "35+")
  ) |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3) +
  scale_colour_manual(
    values = c(
      "Female" = "#004488",
      "Male" = "#ddaa33",
      "Non-Binary" = "#bb5566"
    )
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    cols = vars(age_cat)
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "No relationship between memory and fingerprint matching ability",
    x = "Corsi foward memory score",
    y = "Fingerprint matching (max 40)",
    colour = "Gender"
  )
  • The labs() function is very useful here.
  • Can use names from aesthetic mapping (aes())
  • Also, title, subtitle and other options.

Fix up labels

Saving with ggsave()

my_plot <- prints |> 
  mutate(
    age_cat = if_else(age < 35, "18-34", "35+")
  ) |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = corsi_fwd,
      y = fingerprint,
      colour = gender
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(width=0.3) +
  scale_colour_manual(
    values = c(
      "Female" = "#004488",
      "Male" = "#ddaa33",
      "Non-Binary" = "#bb5566"
    )
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    cols = vars(age_cat)
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "No relationship between memory and fingerprint matching ability",
    x = "Corsi foward memory score",
    y = "Fingerprint matching (max 40)",
    colour = "Gender"
  )

ggsave(
  here('images', 'memory_plot.tiff'),
  plot = my_plot,
  width = 15,
  height = 10,
  units = "cm",
  dpi = 500
)
  • Save plot to variable.
  • Use ggsave() function
  • Can input requirements from publishers.
  • You may need to adjust text sizes, etc, manually.
    • Note: plot element sizes are in mm.

Saving with ggsave()

Another kind of plot

prints |> 
  mutate(
    age_cat = if_else(age < 35, "18-34", "35+")
  ) |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = age_cat,
      y = artificial_print
    )
  ) +
  geom_boxplot(
    fill = "grey",
    alpha = 0.5
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Age category",
    y = "Artifical print score (max 40)"
  )

Another kind of plot

The cheat sheet

  • There is a very good cheat sheet.
  • https://rstudio.github.io/cheatsheets/html/data-visualization.html
  • Particularly good for identifying appropriate geom_ functions.
